text: Well, the thing i cant get my head around is this: For pre event, i get a bunch of historical info, i can process that in some way and come up with a price. If i did a good job, i ll be making money. Now inplay, i may still have my modelled price, but now i need to adjust it (or even completly forget about it). So now all i have is: someone says the horse should be priced 3.4. Now i need some extra information that tells me its not actually 3.4, otherwise i m not matching anything.

elements.text: Well, the thing i cant get my head around is this: For pre event, i get a bunch of historical info, i can process that in some way and come up with a price. If i did a good job, i ll be making money. Now inplay, i may still have my modelled price, but now i need to adjust it (or even completly forget about it). So now all i have is: someone says the horse should be priced 3.4. Now i need some extra information that tells me its not actually 3.4, otherwise i m not matching anything.

text: Cross market bets could maybe in theory work, but the 1 second delay makes this look really difficult to me

elements.text: Cross market bets could maybe in theory work, but the 1 second delay makes this look really difficult to me

text:
Horse racing Inplay is certainly a different beast, you have odds flying from sub 2 to above 100 and back again, there is value to be had all over the place in most races. For me it’s all about taking advantage of this volatility and getting matched at prices/value I really shouldn’t be. 

The trick is accurately pricing the market as best you can so you know when and where the value is, then you have the hard part which is getting matched, easy at low stakes but progressively harder as you scale up.

elements.text: Horse racing Inplay is certainly a different beast, you have odds flying from sub 2 to above 100 and back again, there is value to be had all over the place in most races. For me it’s all about taking advantage of this volatility and getting matched at prices/value I really shouldn’t be.

The trick is accurately pricing the market as best you can so you know when and where the value is, then you have the hard part which is getting matched, easy at low stakes but progressively harder as you scale up.

text:
_"The trick is accurately pricing the market as best you can so you know when and where the value is"_
But how do you do this if all you use is the price given to you in the market? What makes you think that a certain price is wrong, when you cant compare it to any other information?

elements.text: "The trick is accurately pricing the market as best you can so you know when and where the value is"
But how do you do this if all you use is the price given to you in the market? What makes you think that a certain price is wrong, when you cant compare it to any other information?

text: I kinda tried something like that, but the difficulity already started getting any order placed. Basically i just wanted to place an order far away (for example: current price is 4, so i just put one at 3) and then hope that the price goes closer and from there cancel when i think its not good anymore. 90% of the time i would get that order in and it would also make a small profit, but in 10% the price moved a lot in the 1second so full volume got matched immediatly and the matched price was awfull compared to what is offered now.

elements.text: I kinda tried something like that, but the difficulity already started getting any order placed. root.text: <@U0128E7BEHW> So there is £294 matches on this 22:05@Cranbourne so far. 4 minutes to go. Do you think it'll go crazy just before the race starts?

text: there isn't that much volatility generally tbh, the markets generally stay quite stable and tight towards the off
